COLIN.</br>Here, Blowszybee, here at the stile,</br>You've pent your sheep, let's rest a while.</br>What happen'd at the busy town,</br>That makes blyth William look so down?
BLOWSZYBEE.</br>H—s he loves, the brightest maid—
COLIN.</br>I wonder'd why his oxen stray'd,</br>His sheep and heifers pine'd unfed:</br>In love!  the riddle's clear; you know</br>When first fair Rose I woo'd, 'twas so.

BLOWSZYBEE.</br>Ay, William, late the blythest swain,</br>That trode the lawn, or flowery plain,</br>To list'ning nymphs, cou'd best rehearse,</br>Love-tale, or cartch, in easy verse;</br>Who like him, Chevy-chase cou'd sing?</br>Who nimbler jig of all the ring?</br>Tho' Scottish bards may boast their play,</br>His flute wou'd swell with sweetest lay:</br>The jolly hunt how oft hae's led,</br>O'er hill and dale with winged speed,</br>Eager to foil the bounding deer,</br>The wiley fox, and shifting hare?</br>Nor winged flight, nor shifting wiles,</br>Cou'd save 'em from his deadly toils.</br>All, all superior powers obey—</br>Our William's self is Cupid's prey.</br>At Bristol which to London's fame,</br>Submits as Severn to great Thame;</br>Yet other towns as much exceeds,</br>As the tall alder whispering reeds;</br>Where ships that tides of wealth convey,</br>Like a thick forest crowd the key,</br>There stands on Avon's buzzing side,</br>An ancient pile of reverend pride:</br>Where pious dames in garments neat,</br>To hear the tuneful organs meet.</br>Adjoining lyes a spacious green,</br>Around are stately fabricks seen,</br>Where cloister'd maids (with unmov'd heart</br>Who long had seen their lovers smart)</br>Too late, alas!  now kinder grown,</br>Reluctant pass their nights alone.</br>Ye blooming maids from them beware—</br>Since nor coming looks, nor daily pray'r,</br>Nought can avail; but heaven we find,</br>Denial thus repays in kind.</br>I'th midst a cross with tow'ring head</br>Glistens like guilded ginger-bread;</br>Around it throng at evening tide</br>Exulting in embroider'd pride,</br>Avona's nymphs, with beaux so bright,</br>In guilded coat, and stockings white:</br>Among the rest comes William too,</br>With ruffled hand, and coat of blue,</br>His lolling head was void of care,</br>His hat aside with careless air,</br>His nose with smutty snuff was tann'd,</br>A slender wan wav'd in his hand—</br>—But see Harissa trips along,</br>Encircled by th' admiring throng;</br>Her rising breast and falling waste,</br>By bright flame colour'd tunic's grac'd;</br>Sad emblem of the lambent pain,</br>She lights in every gazing swain!</br>Her shining myrtle-colour'd hair,</br>Shadows her face, like lilly fair;</br>Her lips with soft persuasion move,</br>Her eyes like Cupid's arrows rove;</br>Nor are her eyes less fatal found,</br>Alike they dart, alike they wound.</br>Admiring fops her beauties tell,</br>And envious nymphs with vapours swell.</br>'Twas now now, that with a side-long look</br>Poor William thro' the heart was struck,</br>In thro' his eyes the mischief pass'd,</br>Like frightened boor he stands a ghast;</br>Harissa with triumphant smile,</br>Observ'd him taken in her toil:</br>With cruel haste, and scornful air,</br>Then left him sinking in despair.</br>In lonely shades he seek for ease,</br>His once dear sports forget to please,</br>No more he wakes the grey-ey'd morn,</br>With clear Hey-rogues or cheerful horn,</br>No more great Piercy's fate he sings,</br>No more delights in sportive rings,</br>Thoughtful and mute the live-long day</br>He sits, or pipes in mournful lay.</br>The gather in swains desire to know,</br>The dread occasion of his woe;</br>When William rais'd his pensive head,</br>And to the pitying Shepherds said:</br>For fair Harissa, friends, I sigh,</br>Relent Harissa, or I dye.
COLIN.</br>Ha!  luckless youth!  come take thy crook,</br>'Tis late, twice four the clock has struck,—</br>The nymphs with equal passion move,</br>Or, lord, defend us swains from love.</br>
